Application Site
The application relates to a site on the junction of Derwent Avenue and Grasmere Avenue, Kingston Vale. The site was previously occupied by a two storey dwelling but this has since been demolished (through planning application 17/14763/FUL). The site is within the Kingston Hill / Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. The site has a Public Transport Accessibility Level of 1b (very poor) and is located within Flood Zone 1 (low probability)

Permission was granted under 22/00304/FUL  dated 29.03.2022 for the erection of two storey single family dwelling with roof accommodation and basement with associated amenity space, off street parking, perimetre wall, electric access gates, cycle storage and refuse/recycling store

This application seeks to amend this permission. Officers note the permission granted was not subject to a legal agreement. 

Proposal
The application seeks to allow conversion of a single dwelling house approved under planning permission ref: 22/00304/FUL into 2nos of dwelling houses. It is indicated on the submitted application form that the development approved under the permission has not started.

Consultation
14 neighbouring properties have been notified and 1 objection has been received stating;
 - Access or traffic problems
 - Car park issues
 - Excessive height or bulk of buildings
 - Privacy

Assessment
The key areas of assessment are:
- Principle of Development;

Principle of Development
Officers acknowledge that an assessment was completed under the previous permission in relation to the suitable principle of development with regards to a single family dwelling.

This application proposes the creation of two separate dwelling with would need to be fully reassessed under the material considerations of such a development including future impact on the highways ect.

Insufficient information has been submitted with this application that would allow officers to make a full assessment and therefore the local planning authority is unable to assess the accessibility of those changes

It is therefore considered that the proposed amendments would fundamentally alter the development approved under planning permission ref: 22/00304/FUL and as officers have been unable to assess the proposed impact of the proposed development fully, permission should be refused.

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer Report

Application Site
The site comprises a semi detached dwelling located within the Flood Zone 2.

Proposal 
Erection of first floor rear extension above the existing balcony.

Consultations
3 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  

The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,
- Flood Risk; and,
- Fire Safety

Character and Appearance
When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer Comment: The proposed first floor rear extension to replace the existing balcony, given its modest scale, siting and the proposed design, is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. 

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment: 
It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Flood Risk
Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.

Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. 

As the proposal relates to the first floor rear extension and therefore the floor level within the proposed development would be set no lower than the existing levels, the mitigation measures are not applicable in this case. 

Fire Safety
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Planning History
23/03187/HOU Demolition of existing rear extension, erection of single storey rear, front infill and first floor side extension. Fenestration alteration.

Application Site
The  site comprises a terrace dwelling.  

Planning Assessment  
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings
- Fire Safety 

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer comment : The proposal seeks approval for the demolition of existing rear extension ,erection of single storey rear, front infill and first floor infill  and first floor side extension. Fenestration alterations.

The existing rear extension is a conservatory and at its widest ('bay window) has a depth of 3.58m. It has an existing width of 5.31m. The proposed rear extension would extend a depth of 4.2m and width of 8.43m which would accommodate the further extension of the existing side extension. The proposed height of the rear extension would be 3.302 to eaves and 3.543m to the pitch of the proposed rooflight. Overall, Officers note that the proposed depth of the extension  for a terrace property would be contrary to Policy Guidance 33 in the Residential Design SPD and therefore would not be considered to be a proportionate and subordinate addition to the dwelling.

In addition to the above, the proposal seeks permission for a first floor side extension  which would be accommodated within the reduced building footprint of the ground floor side extension. This additional floor level would result in a change of roof form of the side extension reverting from a flat roof to a hipped roof form arrangement. Overall, the addition of both the proposed first floor extension and the hipped roof form to the existing side extension would fail to appear subordinate or proportional and unduly reduce the gap between the dwelling and its neighbouring dwelling at no 47 Compton Crescent. This element of the proposed development is therefore considered to be unacceptable in timers of scale, siting and design. It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.

The proposal seeks approval for a front infill to the dwelling between the garage and the front door in order to create internal floorspace to accommodate a shower room. Officers note this would be set back from the front building line of the property and this would be deemed acceptable.

In addition, Officers note the proposal also includes the introduction of a mono pitch tiled roof to front the garage, infill and the front door which would have an eaves height 2.786m and pitch height  abutting the main dwelling of 3.581m. This would alter the character and appearance of the front elevation of the dwelling and would be deemed acceptable. 

Officers note proposed materials would match existing .

Overall, the proposed development is therefore considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, siting and design. It is considered that there would be unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals. 

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

The principal property  to consider in relation to amenity is neighbouring property at no 51 Compton Crescent.

Given the siting and depth of the proposed development hard on the boundary with no51 , it is considered that the proposed development would result in the significant loss of daylight to the closest habitable room at ground level in comparison with the existing situation.

In addition given the siting and depth  of the proposed development along the shared boundary with no 51, it is considered that the proposed development would constitute an unneighbourly form of development present an overbearing appearance in the location.

Overall, given the size of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring no51 Compton Crescent, it is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of  overbearing appearance and loss of light. 

Fire safety 
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation  assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12 (A). the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons. Officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

Conclusion 
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Residential Use 
Policy CS10 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 sets out the Borough's housing targets as defined by the London Plan, 2011. Policy H1 (Increasing Housing Supply) of the London Plan (2021) sets ten-year targets for net housing completions that each local planning authority should plan for. Table 4.1 sets out the 10 year targets for net housing completions in each London Borough from 2019/20 - 2028/29). The requirement for Kingston is to deliver 9,640 homes in this 10 year period, which would equate to 964 net completions per annum.

As there is no 5-year housing land supply, paragraph 11 of the NPPF indicates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole.  These considerations should be given considerable weight in the assessment of any forthcoming planning application.

The proposed development seeks planning permission for a two-bed residential flat arranged over the ground and first floors of the building.

The principle of creating a residential unit within an established predominantly residential area is acceptable subject to compliance with Development Plan policies. 

Loss of / Reduction of Retail Floorspace
Paragraph 81 of the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (2021) sets out that: 'Planning policies and decisions should help create the conditions in which businesses can invest, expand and adapt. Significant weight should be placed on the need to support economic growth and productivity, taking into account both local business needs and wider opportunities for development.' 

Policy DM17 (Protecting Existing Employment Land and Premises) sets out that the Council will protect all employment land and premises to enhance its vitality and viability and promote employment growth through regeneration initiatives including new and improved facilities, improvements to the quality of the office stock, access and public realm.

Policy DM17 is clear that alternative uses will not be acceptable unless it has been demonstrated by sound evidence and rigorous marketing over a number of years (up to two years) that there is no quantitative or qualitative need for a range of employment uses. Mixed use development schemes should not result in a net loss of employment capacity (floorspace and/or land) and should not compromise the viability of the site and/or its surroundings for employment purposes.

Impact upon Highway Safety
Policy T6 of the London Plan (2021) sets out that car-free development should be the starting point for all development proposals in places that are well-connected by public transport, with developments elsewhere designed to provide the minimum necessary parking ('car-lite'). Car-free development has no general parking but should still provide disabled persons parking in line with Part E of this policy.

Policies DM9 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy (2012) seek to ensure that new development has regard to local traffic conditions, and does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.

The site is located in an area with a PTAL rating of 1b (very poor). Table 10.3 (Maximum Residential Parking Standards) of the London Plan (2021) sets out a maximum car parking provision in Outer London areas with a PTAL 0-1 of up to 1.5 spaces per dwelling for 1-2 bedroom units.

The site is located within a Controlled Parking Zone (Zone G). It is noted that the proposal involves the loss of an existing garage to the rear of the site which is accessed off Balmoral Road. The proposed ground floor plan shows provision of off-street car parking for 1no. vehicle to be behind gates accessed off Balmoral Road. This is considered to be acceptable, subject to the applicant entering into a legal agreement to prohibit the future owners/occupiers of the proposed flat from obtaining on-street resident parking permits. 

In the absence of a signed legal agreement to prevent occupiers or visitors to the proposed unit from obtaining a residents parking or visitors parking permit to mitigate any parking pressures, the proposed development would not comply with Paragraph 107 of the NPPF 2021, Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.  

The London Plan 2021 Table 10.2 requires minimum of 2no. cycle spaces per 2+ bedroom unit. The application form and accompanying plans do not provide for any dedicated cycle parking spaces. Therefore, the proposal fails to comply with Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021.

Overall, the proposals are not in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012 or Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021.

Refuse / Recycling Management
Policy CS9 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires integrated, well-designed recycling facilities to be incorporated into all new developments.

Policy Guidance 22 of the Council's Residential Design SPD 2013 provides further guidance on this matter, stating that the storage of waste facilities should be integral to the design of dwellings and located so that they can be accessed conveniently for residents. Ideally, they should be to the rear of the property, provided that a route between the front and rear of the property can be provided that does not go through the house.

Refuse and recycling bin storage has not been shown on the submitted plans. As such, insufficient information has been provided of the proposed refuse/recycling storage arrangements at this site for Officers to make a considered assessment of the suitability of this aspect of the proposals.

Contribution to Community Infrastructure Levy (CIL)
As of the 1st November 2015 the Council commenced the operation of a Community Infrastructure Levy (CIL) as a means of collecting monies to provide local infrastructure to offset the impact of developments. This replaced the S106 mechanism for collecting contributions for local infrastructure e.g. education and health with the exception of affordable housing. For the avoidance of doubt S106 contributions can only be collected to resolve site specific issues as a result of the proposed development.

For Kingston CIL purposes, the proposed development is located within CIL Zone 2 with a charge of £130 per square metre of residential development. 

The application would also be liable to pay Mayoral CIL (MCIL2) currently set at £60 per square metre. The CIL charges are subject to the national Tender Price Index. In the event that the All-in Tender Price Index ceases to be published, the index referred to is the retail prices index; and the figure for a given year is the figure for November of the preceding year.

Conclusion
The proposed development would convert the ground floor space to residential use to merge with the existing residential floorspace at first floor in order to create a 2-bedroom residential dwellinghouse. As such, there would be no net increase to the Borough's housing supply. This is given neutral weighting.

The standard of accommodation is considered to be logical and would comply with space standards for a 2-bedroom, 3-person dwellinghouse. However, as with the previous application submission, there is limited dedicated storage space indicated against the minimum policy requirements and the applicant has failed to demonstrate floor to ceiling heights across the proposed development and so officers cannot properly assess this aspect. Both matters are assigned moderate weighting against the proposals. 

A fire safety strategy has been submitted as part of the application. This is given neutral weighting.

The proposal would include one off-street car parking space to the rear and so not result in a loss of the existing off-street parking provision. However, in the absence of a signed legal agreement to car cap the development and prevent the issue of on-street car parking permits for residents/visitors of this property, the proposal would exacerbate pressure for on-street parking and prejudice highway safety. This is given significant weighting against the proposals.

As with the previous application submission, the proposals do not demonstrate any cycle parking to serve the residential dwellinghouse and there is also no refuse/recycling storage indicated for the dwellinghouse. These matters are given significant weighting against the proposals.

The proposed development is in conflict with the development plan and it is considered that the adverse impacts of granting permission would significantly and demonstrably outweigh any benefits associated with its proposed conversion to a single dwellinghouse, when assessed against the policies in the NPPF as a whole.

It is therefore recommended that the application be refused.

The Local Lead Flood Authority raise an objection to the submitted details for the following reasons:

The Flood Map for Surface Water (FMfSW) provided by the Environment Agency shows that the site lies in an area of very low risk of surface water flooding (meaning there is less than 0.1% likelihood of flooding occurring in a given year). An online version of this mapping data is available to view through the Environment Agency's Long term flood risk information mapping.

The applicant has proposed to discharge surface water at a restricted rate of 1 l/s into Thames Water combined sewer network. SuDS in the form of an underground attenuation tank, and green roof has been incorporated to contribute to sustainable surface water drainage by attenuating flow. Additionally, a hydrobrake device has also been incorporated. Infiltration and discharge to a watercourse has been discounted due to site geology/site constraints and absence of a nearby watercourse respectively. It is stated that "Due to the soil conditions, which will provide a low level of infiltration, the size of the site and restriction on the proximity of soakaways to buildings (5m) and boundaries (2.5m) traditional soakaways will not be suitable for the site." However, the current proposal to discharge surface water to the existing combined sewer does not comply with paragraph 056 of the Planning Practice Guidance (PPG) and policy SI 13 of the London Plan. Furthermore, the information shared by the Water Company with the Local Authority shows separate sewers in this location, and in accordance with the Water Industry Act 1991 a surface water connection may not be connected to a foul water sewer without consent of the sewerage undertaker. The applicant should aim to discharge surface runoff as high up the hierarchy of drainage options as reasonably practicable
(in this case, into the surface water sewer). There is a surface water sewer that runs in front of
Adelaide Road.

The applicant has stated in the drainage strategy that at the currently proposed discharge rate of 1 l/s, an attenuation volume of 10.44 m3 is required for a return period of 1:100 years, with a 40% allowance for climate change. However, drainage calculations are required to support this. Drainage calculations should be provided to demonstrate that the proposed drainage system (at the proposed runoff rates) can contain up to the 1 in 30 storm event without flooding and that any onsite flooding between the 1 in 30 and the 1 in 100 plus 40% climate change storm event should be safely contained on site. These calculations include details of critical storm durations as required. Drainage calculations should include all areas that contribute to the drainage system, including soft landscaping areas where they contribute to the drainage system.

A surface water drainage layout has been provided as required to show the location of all proposed drainage components and the connectivity of the system. The layout as required also shows the gradient, pipe numbers and pipe sizes, together with storage volumes of the proposed underground attenuation tank. A revised drainage layout should be provided following changes in the proposed discharge point in compliance with the drainage hierarchy.

A maintenance schedule for the surface water drainage system has been provided; showing the
maintenance tasks and frequencies for the tanked permeable paving, hydrobrake and other drainage components. It has been confirmed that the landowner shall be responsible for the maintenance of the proposed drainage system.

The LLFA do not recommend the discharge of this condition because of drainage hierarchy concerns and because more information is still required to support the discharge of this condition. To comply with the Planning Policy Guidance and the Policy SI 13 of the London Plan, the applicant should consider discharging surface water higher up the drainage hierarchy (in this case, a surface water sewer), or provide suitable justification where this is not feasible. Drainage calculations should be provided to demonstrate that the proposed drainage system (at the proposed runoff rate) can contain up to the 1 in 30 storm event without flooding and that any onsite flooding between the 1 in 30 and the 1 in 100 plus 40% climate change storm event should be safely contained on site. A revised drainage layout should be provided where necessary.

Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. 

The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.
